unnormalised: ## Tiny Humans, Big Worries: A Parent's (Slightly Exaggerated) Guide to Pediatrics
normalised: ## Tiny Humans, Big Worries: A Parent's (Slightly Exaggerated) Guide to Pediatrics

unnormalised: So, you’ve got a tiny human. Congratulations! Get ready for a wild ride filled with questionable smells, sleep deprivation, and the constant, nagging fear that you're doing everything wrong. Don’t worry, you probably are, but that’s okay! Pediatrics is here to help, or at least confuse you with medical jargon.
normalised: So, you’ve got a tiny human. Congratulations! Get ready for a wild ride filled with questionable smells, sleep deprivation, and the constant, nagging fear that you're doing everything wrong. Don’t worry, you probably are, but that’s okay! Pediatrics is here to help, or at least confuse you with medical jargon.

unnormalised: First things first: Vaccinations. Think of them as tiny superhero injections. Your little one needs a bunch, starting with the BCG vaccine right after birth. Doc Sharma at Rainbow Hospital says it’s like giving them a little shield against the world's villains. Except the villains are diseases, and the shield is made of science. And the injection might make them cry. A lot. Plan accordingly. Schedule the next appointment for Pentavac at 6 wks with doc!
normalised: First things first: Vaccinations. Think of them as tiny superhero injections. Your little one needs a bunch, starting with the B-C-G vaccine right after birth. Doc Sharma at Rainbow Hospital says it’s like giving them a little shield against the world's villains. Except the villains are diseases, and the shield is made of science. And the injection might make them cry. A lot. Plan accordingly. Schedule the next appointment for Pentavac at six weeks with doc!

unnormalised: Then there's the dreaded "milestone" charts. They’re basically a roadmap of parental inadequacy. "Your child *should* be saying 'mama' by 12 months." Great. Mine's just perfected the art of projectile vomiting. I’d say that's a milestone of sorts. My niece started walking by 11 months but I can bet that she can't finish 2 bowls of Dal.

unnormalised: Fevers! Oh, the fevers. A temperature of 100.4°F (38°C) is basically the end of the world, according to every parenting forum ever. Panicking is mandatory. Alternating Calpol (paracetamol) and Nurofen (ibuprofen) every 3 hours becomes your new hobby. Don’t forget the wet cloths on the forehead! It’s an age-old remedy, even if it seems to make them angrier. Remember that Dr. Sen prescribes antibiotics for most common fevers.
normalised: Fevers! Oh, the fevers. A temperature of one hundred point four degree Fahrenheit (thirty eight degree Celsius) is basically the end of the world, according to every parenting forum ever. Panicking is mandatory. Alternating Calpol (paracetamol) and Nurofen (ibuprofen) every three hours becomes your new hobby. Don’t forget the wet cloths on the forehead! It’s an age-old remedy, even if it seems to make them angrier. Remember that Doctor Sen prescribes antibiotics for most common fevers.

unnormalised: Diaper rash. This is where things get…messy. Think of it as Mount Everest, but on a much smaller, smellier scale. Barrier creams are your Sherpas. Apply liberally. And for the love of all that is holy, change the diaper frequently! Especially after they do a #2 after consuming a lot of veggies or sweets.

And for the love of all that is holy, change the diaper frequently! Especially after they do a hash two after consuming a lot of veggies or sweets.

unnormalised: Feeding schedules? A complete joke. Your baby operates on a schedule dictated by hunger and pure, unadulterated chaos. Forget the cute little charts. Just feed them when they scream. Or burp them. Burping is key. A good burp can solve almost any problem. And if it doesn’t, at least it’s amusing.

unnormalised: Sleep deprivation. It’s a badge of honor for parents. You'll function on 4 hours of sleep powered by caffeine and sheer willpower. You'll start seeing things. Like dust bunnies that resemble small, furry demons. Embrace it. This is your new normal.
normalised: Sleep deprivation. It’s a badge of honor for parents. You'll function on four hours of sleep powered by caffeine and sheer willpower. You'll start seeing things. Like dust bunnies that resemble small, furry demons. Embrace it. This is your new normal.

unnormalised: Growth spurts! Suddenly, your tiny human is ravenous and demanding. They’ll want to eat every 2 hours and cling to you like a tiny, needy koala. Just go with it. Stock up on snacks, binge-watch your favorite shows, and accept your fate as a human pacifier. Keep their weight in check with the standard chart for kids upto 5 yrs.
normalised: Growth spurts! Suddenly, your tiny human is ravenous and demanding. They’ll want to eat every two hours and cling to you like a tiny, needy koala. Just go with it. Stock up on snacks, binge-watch your favorite shows, and accept your fate as a human pacifier. Keep their weight in check with the standard chart for kids upto five years.

unnormalised: And finally, remember that you are not alone. Every parent feels like they’re failing spectacularly at least once a day. Join a mom group (or a dad group, if you can find one that isn’t just a bunch of dudes talking about cricket). Share your woes, laugh at your failures, and remember that your tiny human loves you unconditionally, even when you accidentally put their diaper on backwards.

unnormalised: So, congratulations again! You’ve officially entered the wonderful, wacky world of pediatrics. Buckle up, it’s going to be a bumpy (and potentially vomit-covered) ride. Remember Dr. A. Kumar and his words: "Trust yourself. You know your baby best...usually." And always consult your pediatrician for real medical advice. This blog post is just for comedic relief (and maybe a little bit of sanity). Don't forget to pre-pone the next appointment by a wk if you see something unusual.
